Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation: Understanding Student Perceptions of Engineering Stress Culture (ESC)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Stress is a salient feature for undergraduate students that has negative effects on student performance, retention, and experience. Previous work has shown that engineering students perceive particularly high levels of stress and anxiety about their grades and course performance. While these studies have identified triggers of stress in individuals, the current project aims to unravel how stress is perceived and propagated as a social norm in engineering and the resulting impact on students. Specifically, the objective of the Engineering Stress Culture project is to understand how students perceive stress as part of the culture of engineering disciplines and how this impacts their development of a sense of inclusion in engineering and identity as engineers. The perception that stress is part of studying engineering or being an engineer is detrimental to student persistence and success in engineering disciplines. Understanding student perceptions of stress will improve student experience, performance, and retain talented students in the engineering disciplines.

The goal of the Engineering Stress Culture project is to characterize the role of stress and identify the ways in which stress can impact students developing an engineering identity. Our study will explore the overall research question: How does the Engineering Stress Culture (ESC) impact students' perception of their engineering discipline or their level of identification with engineering? This two-year project will involve both quantitative surveys and qualitative interviews that will collectively elucidate the relationships between engineering student stress, identity, and inclusion. The results of the study will be used to understand how students experience stress as part of their engineering education and its impacts on forming an engineering identity. While sources of anxiety and stress for individual students have been documented, students' perception of stress being part of the culture of their discipline is not well-understood. Our proposed study will enhance our understanding by 1) characterizing students' perceptions of ESC and potential variation among majors and 2) determining the relationships between constructs including anxiety, stress, perceptions of inclusion, and identification with their engineering major. Understanding what students view as stressful and how students identify stress as an element of program culture will support the development of interventions to mitigate student stress. Interventions to reduce stress through program design and administration will benefit student recruitment, retention, and success, all of which will support efforts to broaden participation in engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nationally, higher education is grappling with a mental health crisis, with concerning numbers of students reporting high levels of stress, anxiety, and depression, which has led to widespread issues with student retention and overburdened university counseling services, among other impacts. While the detrimental effects of stress and anxiety on college students are acknowledged by students, instructors, and researchers, it is has not been studied how stress can be associated with the culture of an academic discipline and how this impacts student feelings of identity and inclusion in that discipline. Further, limited work has specifically studied mental health of engineering students, despite evidence suggesting that engineering culture is unique compared to other academic disciplines. In this study, we surveyed and interviewed engineering students to understand the prevalence of mental health challenges, their relationships to engineering identity and perceptions of inclusion, and to better understand the student experience related to mental health in engineering. The overall project goal was to raise awareness for engineering undergraduate mental health and to provide the groundwork for developing proactive interventions for students. Our study included a large sample size of over 1,000 undergraduate engineering students of varying demographics and disciplines who responded to a quantitative survey. Interviews were conducted with 30 of the survey participants across engineering disciplines. The results of the study are being used to create a dialogue about undergraduate engineering student mental health at the university of study and nationally.

Our research found that the prevalence of stress, anxiety, and depression is high for undergraduate engineering students. The results of the study found that female students report higher levels of stress and anxiety compared to male students. The study further identified relationships between measures of self-reported mental health and department inclusion. Interview results revealed that undergraduate engineering students conceptualize the relationships between stress, anxiety, and depression inconsistently, and the results identified common stressors for engineering students. Interviews also identified common stressors for engineering students. Additionally, student surveys and interviews indicated that students often associate poor mental health with studying engineering, and that students view poor self-care as a norm in engineering. Our findings suggest that students from different backgrounds experience different rates of mental health challenges in engineering, which indicate the need for interventions that are tailored to student groups. Further, our findings about perceived norms in engineering culture and the factors that contribute to the perpetuation of these norms will be important in efforts towards developing a more positive and inclusive culture in engineering.

Collectively these results can be used to develop proactive interventions to support the positive mental wellbeing of engineering undergraduate students. These future interventions can support the dismantling of unhealthy norms, lower the risk of exacerbating effects for students with existing mental health issues, and encourage a healthier working environment for students. Reducing student perceptions of a stress culture can boost retention, reduce the load on counseling services, and support broadening participation efforts in engineering, as students who are underrepresented in engineering programs may experience microaggressions in addition to academic stress. The survey developed as part of this work could also be adapted for use at other institutions and for other groups (e.g., graduate students). Additionally, the results of our study have created the groundwork for the development of survey tools that will be used in future studies. In sum, by understanding the prevalence of mental health challenges of undergraduate engineering students, their relationship to identity and perceptions of inclusion, and how students and faculty can normalize and reinforce these challenges, we believe that educators can develop more proactive approaches to supporting student wellbeing.
